content.title: Renal Transplant Vascular Techniques
content.definition: Vascular anastomotic techniques for kidney transplantation, including arterial and venous connections to recipient iliac vessels.

key_concepts.description: Renal artery to external iliac artery (end-to-side). Renal vein to external iliac vein (end-to-side).
30-35% of kidneys have multiple renal arteries. May require bench reconstruction with Carrel patch or conjoined anastomosis.
Aortic patch containing renal artery origins from deceased donor. Allows single anastomosis for multiple arteries.

arterial_anastomosis.standard: End renal artery to side external iliac artery using 5-0 or 6-0 polypropylene
arterial_anastomosis.internal_iliac: End-to-end to internal iliac artery (alternative if EIA diseased)

multiple_arteries.bench_techniques: Spatulation and conjoined anastomosis, use of aortic Carrel patch

venous_anastomosis.standard: End renal vein to side external iliac vein using 5-0 polypropylene
venous_anastomosis.considerations: Right renal vein shorter than left - may need vein extension graft in living donor

vascular_quality_assessment: Inspect for intimal flaps before anastomosis
Doppler confirmation of flow after reperfusion

arterial.thrombosis: 0.5-2% incidence. Usually technical error. Requires immediate re-exploration.
arterial.stenosis: 1-5% incidence. May present late with hypertension. Treat with angioplasty or surgical revision.

venous.thrombosis: 1-4% incidence. More common than arterial. Often leads to graft loss.
venous.risk_factors: Technical error, hypercoagulable state, compression from hematoma

special_situations.calcified_iliac: Use aorta if available, or consider common iliac or use donor iliac extension graft
special_situations.pediatric_donor: May require en bloc transplant with aortic and IVC segments

outcomes.graft_survival_1yr: 92-95% for deceased donor, 95-98% for living donor

citations: Nghiem DD, et al. Management of multiple renal arteries in kidney transplantation. J Urol. 2000;164:1366-1369

learning_objectives: Describe standard vascular anastomoses in renal transplantation
Explain options for managing multiple renal arteries
List vascular complications and their management
Discuss special situations requiring modified vascular techniques
clinical_pearls: Always flush graft with cold preservation solution immediately before reperfusion
Doppler confirms arterial and venous flow before closing
Immediate re-exploration for suspected vascular complication - time is graft survival
